a b s t r a c t
Much attention have been recently paid to the upper Ordovician Wufeng shale (O3w) and lower Silurian Longmaxi shale (S1l) in the Jiaoshiba area of Sichuan Basin, which is now the largest producing shale gas field in China. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), low pressure gas (N2 and CO2) adsorption, helium pycnometry, X-ray diffraction and geochemical analyses were performed to investigate the pore structure and fractal dimension of the pores in O3w-S1l shale formation in the Jiaoshiba area. FE-SEM images show that organic matter (OM) pores are dominant in the organic-rich samples and these pores are often irregular, bubble-like, elliptical and faveolate in shape, while in organic-poor samples, limited and isolated interparticle (interP), intraparticle (intraP) and OM pores are observed. Reversed S-shaped isotherms obtained from nitrogen adsorption are type Ⅱ, and hysteresis loops indicate that the shape of micropore in the samples is slit-or plate-like. BET surface areas and total pore volume vary from 12.2 to 27.1 m2/g and from 1.8 10 2 to 2.9 10 2 cm3/g, with an average of 19.5 m2/g and 2.3 10 2 cm3/g, respectively. Adsorption volume from both N2 and CO2 adsorption increases with respect to TOC contents. Porosities obtained from helium porosimetry are comparable with these from gas (CO2 and N2) adsorption in O3w-S1l shale. However, porosity determined by quantitative FE-SEM analysis is much smaller, which is mainly related to limited resolution and the small areas of investigation.
Based on the Frenkel-Halsey-Hill (FHH) model of low-pressure N2 adsorption, fractal dimensions of the pores varied from 2.737 to 2.823. Relationships between pore structure parameters and TOC content, mineral composition and fractal dimension reveal that the fractal dimension is mainly associated with micropores. Samples with higher TOC content, higher quartz content and lower clay content tend to contain more heterogeneous micropores, resulting in higher fractal dimensions and more complicated pore structure in shales. Therefore, fractal dimension is an effective parameter to reflect the complexity of pore structure and the degree of micropore development in O3w-S1l shale.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As a new and abundant energy resource, unconventional shale gas has already impacted the US energy supply (Bernard et al., 2012; Curtis, 2002), and has become the focus of exploration in Canada, China, Australia and other countries (Chen et al., 2011).
xhu@uta.edu (Q. Hu).
Organic-rich shales, from Precambrian to Tertiary, deposited in marine, transitional marine or lacustrine settings, are widely distributed in China (Hao et al., 2013). According to the estimates issued by the Research Center of Oil and Gas Resources of the Ministry of Land and Resources in China (Zhang et al., 2011), the technically recoverable shale gas resource in China is about 25.1 1012 m3 (886.4 tcf), which is even greater than that of the United States (24.4 1012 m3 or 861.7 tcf).
The Sichuan Basin, with an area of more than 1.8 105 km2, is one of the most gas-productive sedimentary basins in China (Chen et al., 2011; Dai et al., 2014). According to Dai et al. (2014), 21 gas-
bearing zones and 136 gas fields produced 24.2 109 m3 (0.85 tcf) in 2012. The upper Ordovician Wufeng shale (O3w) and lower Silurian Longmaxi shale (S1l) are widespread units in the basin, and their geologic characteristics are similar to these of five leading shale gas producing basins in North America (Pollastro, 2007; Warlick, 2006). Previous studies strongly suggest that O3w-S1l shales in Sichuan Basin, especially in the Jiaoshiba area, are mainly characterized by a high organic matter (OM) content, large thickness, high thermal maturity, strong gas-generation yield and appropriate brittleness (Guo and Zhang, 2014; Guo, 2014; Guo et al., 2014a). Favorable geological conditions for the formation and enrichment of shale gas enable O3w-S1l shale in the Jiaoshiba area a very attractive target for shale gas exploration (Guo and Zhang, 2014; Guo, 2014; Guo et al., 2014a; Jing et al., 2014; Liu et al., 2011; Qiao et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2013). For example, it is reported that the gas production from JY1Well is about 20.3 104 m3 (or 7.17 Mmcf) per day (Guo, 2014; Guo et al., 2014a).
With shale being a complex and heterogeneous porousmedium, its pore structure parameters, such as pore morphology, size distribution, volume and specific surface area, are very important in understanding adsorption, desorption, diffusion and flow of gas in shales (Hu et al., 2014; Loucks et al., 2009). Furthermore, the producibility of shale gas mainly depends on the pores and their connectivity for storing and releasing gas (Mastalerz et al., 2013); thus the pore structure is an important issue to be studied for sustainable shale resource development.
In order to elucidate the pore structure of shale, a range of direct-imaging and indirect methods have been used in the literature. Indirect methods, such as small-angle and ultra-small-angle neutron scattering, gas adsorption (N2, CO2, CH4), Mercury Intrusion Porosimetry (MIP) and helium porosimetry, can provide quantitative and reproducible information about porosity, pore size distribution and surface area for pores down to micropore range (<2 nm in diameter), but are unable to give direct information about pore morphology (Chalmers et al., 2012a; Clarkson et al., 2013; Hemes et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2014). Direct imaging methods include CT-scan, Focused Ion BeamScanning Electron Microscopy, Field Emission-SEM, Transmission ElectronMicroscopy and Broad-Ion-Beam polishing in combination with SEM (Bernard et al., 2012; Clarkson et al., 2013; Desbois et al., 2009; Dong et al., 2015; Hemes et al., 2013; Klaver et al., 2015; Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Zhang et al., 2014). These direct imaging methods are used to observe the geometry and connectivity of pore network, down to nm-scale resolution for some methods.
Furthermore, due to the complexity and variety of shale pores, several researchers proposed different pore classification schemes to describe various pore types in shale formations based on direct imaging methods (Desbois et al., 2009; Kuila et al., 2014; Loucks et al., 2012, 2009; Ma et al., 2015; Slatt and O'Brien, 2011). These pore classification schemes are mainly based on pore size, the accessibility to external fluid (Rouquerol et al., 1994), shape (Rouquerol et al., 1994), and the relationship between pores and particles (Loucks et al., 2012). Pores in shale can also be classified as porous floccules, organic matter pores, fecal pellets, fossil fragments, intraparticle pores and micro-channels and micro-fractures (Slatt and O'Brien, 2011). Both advantages and drawbacks exist in direct-imaging and indirect methods; therefore, a combination of them is a trend for pore structure research. Furthermore, fractal theory has also been applied to depict and quantify the irregularity of the pore structure in several porous media (Avnir and Jaroniec, 1989; Hemes et al., 2013; Jaroniec, 1995; Mahamud and Novo, 2008; Yang et al., 2014).
As the largest producing shale gas field in China, gas production from the O3w-S1l shale in the Jiaoshiba area has exceeded 300 104 m3 (105.9 Mmcf) per day, using horizontal drilling and
multi-stage hydraulic fracturing technologies to create a permeable flow pathway in shale gas systems (Guo, 2014; Guo et al., 2014a; Wang, 2015). However, the pore structure of O3w-S1l shale has not been studied. With a combination of indirect imaging method (FE-SEM) and indirect methods (gas adsorption and helium porosimetry) for O3w-S1l shale, the major objectives of this work are to: (1) characterize the morphology, pore size distribution, specific surface area and volume; (2) compare porosity data obtained from different methods; (3) determine whether the pores are fractal; and (4) identify the main controlling factors on pore development, pore structure and fractal dimension of pores.

sections.heading: 2. Location and geological setting
sections.text:
Geographically, the Jiaoshiba area is located in the Fuling District of Chongqing Municipality, Southwest China, and covers an area of approximately 347 km2 (Fig. 1aeb). Structurally, the Jiaoshiba area is both located in the east district of Sichuan Basin and on the west side of the basin boundary faultdQiyueshan fault (Chen et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2004, 2007; Guo, 2013). As shown in Fig. 1b, the study area contains a wide and gentle anticline confined by several north-east trending faults from the boundary. Drilling reveals that the pressure coefficient, the ratio of the actual fluid pressure versus the corresponding normal hydrostatic pressure at the same depth, is approximately 1.55 at the bottom of O3w-S1l shale (Guo and Zhang, 2014). Overall, the Jiaoshiba structure is relatively stable with little deformation in themiddle part, however, the dip angle at the wings of the anticline is apparently larger and reverse faults are well developed (Fig. 1c).
The Jiaoshiba area has undergone several tectonic movements since the formation of Yangtze Paraplatform (Fig. 2; Tong, 1992), including Caledonian (late Sinian-Silurian), Hercynian (DevonianPermian), Indosinian (Triassic), Yanshanian (Jurassic-late Cretaceous) and Himalayan (Paleogene-Quaternary). Affected by the Caledonian orogeny, Devonian sediments are absent and most of the Carboniferous sediments are eroded with only a thin set of strata (C1) remaining in the study area. Cambrian, Ordovician and Silurian layers are successively deposited until Hercynian deformation, which result in the cessation of deposition on the top of lower Permian. During the period from late Ordovician to early Silurian, two global transgressions caused a low-energy, anoxic sedimentary environment in the study area and deposition of the O3w-S1l formation (Guo and Zhang, 2014; Guo et al., 2014b). The O3w-S1l formation reached its maximum burial depths of approximately 6500 m in late Yanshanian (about 120 Ma), since then the formation undergone threeminor tectonic uplifts during the period of late Yanshanian and Himalayan (Guo and Zhang, 2014; Mei et al., 2010). The present burial depth of the O3w-S1l formation in the study area increases gradually from about 2110 m in northeast region to 2600 m in the southwest, and the maximum thicknesses of the O3w-S1l formation are between 260 and 340 m (Fig. 1bec).
The O3w-S1l shale has been regarded as both a source and seal rock, and it can be subdivided into three members based on lithology (Fig. 2). From the bottom to the top, the lower part of the Longmaxi shale (about 80e120 m thick), including the Wufeng formation, is mainly dominated by black, fine and thick carbonaceous shale, carbonaceous mudstone, argillaceous siltstone and siliceous shale. A large amount of radiolarian, calthrop and graptolite fossils are observed in the fresh shale cores, indicating a deepwater shelf sedimentary environment (Guo, 2013). The middle part (about 30 m thick) consists of gray siltstone interbedded with dark gray argillaceous siltstone, indicating the slope facies. Lastly, the upper part (about 130 m thick) is dominated by dark-gray mudstone and gray shale with fewer fossils, indicating shallow shelf deposition. All samples used in this study come from the
lowermost part of O3w-S1l shale andmost of them are organic-rich.

sections.heading: 3.1. Samples
sections.text: A total of 9 shale samples (chips from fresh cores) were selected from O3w-S1l shale in the JY1 Well (5 samples) and JY11-4 Well (4 samples), which were drilled in 2012 and 2014, respectively. Locations of these wells are shown in Fig. 1b. All samples were chosen from the lowest unit of O3w-S1l shale, taking into consideration the variability of total organic carbon (TOC), in organic composition and vitrinite reflectance (Ro%). Table 1 presents a list of shale samples tested, the formation from which they were sampled, depth, TOC content and thermal maturity. O3w-S1l shale formation is uniformly distributed in the Jiaoshiba area (Fig. 1c); therefore, this set of samples can well represent the bottom portion of O3w-S1l shale. Each sample was cut into several parts for analyzing the mineralogical composition, organic petrography and various porosimetry methods. In order to reduce the potential of drying artefacts, the wet samples were gradually oven dried up to a maximum of about 100 C for FE-SEM.

sections.heading: 3.2. Geochemical analyses
sections.text:
Powdered shale samples (15e25 mg) were prepared in Unconventional Experimental Research Center of Branch Research Institute of Petroleum Exploration and Development of Sinopec East
China, and then analyzed for TOC content with a CS-230 Analyzer (precision of 2%) following the Chinese Oil and Gas Industry Standard (GB/T) 19145-2003; TOC content was determined by subtracting total in organic carbon from total carbon.
Because of the high maturity of O3w-S1l marine shale in the study area, there was not enough vitrinite for measuring a representative number of vitrinite reflectance in the shales, and this conventional geochemistry indicator to evaluate maturity becomes useless (Jacob, 1989; Schoenherr et al., 2007). Consequently, a thermal maturity of bitumen reflectance was measured with MPVⅢ microphotometer 806 apparatus in the Experimental Research Center of Wuxi Research Institute of Petroleum Geology of Sinopec, following the Chinese Oil and Gas Industry Standard (SY/T) 5124- 1995. The analysis was carried out under room temperature of about 23 C (±3 C) and a relative humidity less than 70%. Some publications have established the relationship between the reflectance of bitumen (Rb) and vitrinite reflectance (Ro) when the rock has reached highly-over-mature stages, and it can be expressed by the following linear regression equation: Ro ¼ (Rbþ0.2443)/1.0495 (Schoenherr et al., 2007). Using this equation, the reflectance of bitumen (Rb) can be converted into equivalent vitrinite reflectance (Ro), which is one of the important controlling factors on the development of organic matter pores (Curtis et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 3.3. Mineralogical composition
sections.text:
Mineralogical compositions of the bulk shale sample and the clay fraction (<2 mm) were determined using X-ray diffraction
(XRD) (X'Pert PRO MPD from Panalytical Company) at the National Research Center for Geoanalysis in Beijing. Preparation, analysis and interpretation procedures were conducted following the
Chinese Oil and Gas Industry Standard (SY/T) 5163-2010. Multiple treatments were carried out before clay fraction analyses, including de-oiling, air-drying (60 C) and then cooling to the ambient
temperature and finally being filtered to be less than 40 mm. The working voltage, current and measuring angle range were 40 kV, 40 mA and 5 e90 , respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4. Porosity
sections.text: The total porosity of shale samples was determined at the Key State Laboratory of Oil and Gas Reservoir Geology and Exploitation at Chengdu University of Technology using a technique based on Boyle's Law, by measuring the grain volume under ambient conditions and bulk volume by Archimedes' principle with helium pycnometry. Samples were oven dried at 115 C to a constant weight (±1 mg). Porosity was calculated from the difference between bulk volume and grain volume. Macropore volume is obtained by subtracting the mesopore volume (measured from N2 adsorption) and micropore volume (measured from CO2 adsorption) from the total pore volume (cm3/g), which is described in Section 3.6.

sections.heading: 3.5. Field emission-scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM)
sections.text:
Four shale samples (JY1-01, JY1-04, JY1-08 and JY11-4-03 in Table 1) were selected and prepared to observe the pore morphology. One surface of each sample (10 mm width, 5 mm height and 1.5 mm length) was selected to be polished by argon ion to create a smooth surface using a Hitachi Ion Milling System IM4000 at East China Branch of Sinopec with an acceleration voltage of 3 kV. After that, the sample was coated with gold at a thickness of 10 nm to provide a conductive surface. The samples were then imaged using a JSM-6700F FE-SEM in the State Key Laboratory of Biochemical Engineering in the Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing. A lowest pixel resolution of about 4 nm can be achieved using an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. This method can directly observe the microscopic pore types, morphology and distribution (Loucks et al., 2009; Milliken et al., 2013).
To quantify the pore space shown in the images (as an area percentage), all high-resolution FE-SEM images were processed using Image J software (Abramoff et al., 2004), which has been recently applied to quantitatively analyze porosity in gray-scale SEM images due to its high accuracy and efficiency (Bai et al., 2013; Curtis et al., 2012). The Image J software can be downloaded as a freeware from http://rsbweb.nih.gov/ij/, and details about the image processing using Image J software can be found in Bai et al. (2013) and Tang et al. (2010). The OM porosity was calculated based on the following equations proposed by Shi et al. (2015):
Ø ¼ Øs$uOM$rshale=rOM (1)
where Ø is the ratio of the OM pore volume versus the shale volume (%); Øs is the ratio of the OM pore volume versus organic matter volume (%); rshale is the density of shale, which is obtained from helium porosimetry, g/cm3; rOM is the density of organic matter and generally accepted to be 1.29 g/cm3 (Shi et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 3.6. Low-pressure gas adsorption
sections.text:
Adsorption of N2 was used to quantify the volumes of mesopores (2e50 nm in diameter). The crushed samples (60e80 mesh) were de-watered in a dry oven at 80 C for 4 h, and then desorbed gases and volatiles under vacuum at 70 C for 12 h, before the lowpressure N2 adsorption was performed with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at 196.15 C.Equivalent surface areas (m2/ g) were calculated using the Brunauer Emmette Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.06e0.2, and pore volume was determined with the Barrette Joynere Halenda (BJH) method (Gregg and Sing, 1982). Pore size distributions were obtained from the adsorption branch of the isotherm using the density functional theory (DFT) method assuming cylindrical pores; more details about the DFT method can be found in Lastoskie et al. (1993), Seaton and Walton (1989) and Zhang and Yang (2013).
Carbon dioxide adsorption analyses were performed using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ surface area analyzer. Using CO2 as adsorbate is useful for characterizing the micropore space of organic-rich porous materials (Ross and Bustin, 2009). Sorption of CO2 was calculated within a pressure range of 4 10 4 ~ 3.2 10 2 at 0 C (Ross and Bustin, 2009), and adsorption data can be interpreted based on multiple adsorption theories, such as DubinineRadushkevich (D-R) and Dubinin-Astakhov (D-A) models (Gregg and Sing, 1982), DFT method (Lastoskie et al., 1993; Ravikovitch and Neimark, 2006; Seaton and Walton, 1989). Because the DFT method can offer a more accurate description of the thermodynamic properties of the fluid in the pores (Neimark et al., 2009), the CO2 adsorption data were interpreted with this method in this work. The theory of the volume filling of micropores is a basis for describing microporous structures in carbonaceous materials (Ross and Bustin, 2009). Reported as volume per 100 g (cm3/100 g), micropore volumes were calculated using 17 10 20 m2 for the cross-sectional area of a CO2 molecule (Ross and Bustin, 2009).

sections.heading: 4. Fractal theory
sections.text:
Fractal geometry has been widely applied to describe some irregular and fragmented systems with no characteristic length scale (Mandelbrot, 1983). Fractal dimensions estimated by adsorption have proven to be a useful and reliable petrophysical parameter to depict and quantify the pore structure and complex surface of irregular porous solids (Mahamud and Novo, 2008). A fractal dimension is also an intrinsic characteristic of the surface itself and the accurate estimation of fractal dimension can be determined by processing the original data with a theoretical model (Mahamud and Novo, 2008). Several methods and models, including image analysis (Dathe et al., 2001; Krohn, 1988), fractal Frenkel-Halsey-Hill (FHH) model (Jaroniec, 1995; Tatlier and Erdem-Senatalar, 1999), fractal BET model (Avnir and Jaroniec, 1989; Brunauer et al., 1938; Rouquerol et al., 1994), thermodynamic method (Neǐmark, 1990; Pfeifer et al., 1989), small angle Xray scattering (Jaroniec, 1995; Rouquerol et al., 1994; Wong et al., 1986), MIP (Angulo et al., 1992; Bernal and Bello, 2001) and
electronic energy transfer method (Even et al., 1984), have been used to measure fractal dimensions. Every method has its own drawbacks and advantages, but the fractal FHHmodel based on gas adsorption isotherms has been proved to be an effective method and has beenwidely applied to several porous materials (Avnir and Jaroniec, 1989; Jaroniec, 1995; Ismail and Pfeifer, 1994; Tatlier and Erdem-Senatalar, 1999; Yang et al., 2014). The FHH model can be described by the following equation:
lnðV=VoÞ ¼ constant þ K½lnðlnðPo=PÞÞ (2)
where V is the volume of adsorbed gasmolecules at the equilibrium pressure P; Vo is the monolayer coverage volume; Po denotes the saturation pressure; P is the equilibrium pressure; K is a constant related to fractal dimension and can be obtained by the slope of the plot of lnV versus ln(ln(P/Po)). Then, fractal dimension (D) can be calculated through the following equation: D ¼ Kþ3, or D ¼ 3þ3K. The former is applied in the capillary condensation regime inwhich the hysteresis loops begin to develop, while the latter is used in the case of the van der Waals force (Pfeifer et al., 1989). The value of fractal dimension D usually varies from 2 to 3, and is strongly influenced by the geometrical irregularities and roughness of the surface (Jaroniec, 1995). The closer the D value approaches 3, the more complex and irregular the surfaces are.

sections.heading: 5.1. Organic geochemistry, mineralogy and porosity
sections.text:
Values of TOC contents for O3w-S1l shale vary from 0.75% to 4.03% with an average value of 2.59%, and show an overall increase with respect to the buried depth (Table 1). Bitumen reflectance (Rb) values are between 2.77% and 3.27%, and the equivalent vitrinite reflectance values (Ro*) converted from Rb range from 2.87% to 3.66% with a mean value of 3.21% (Table 1), which indicates that the shale samples are over-mature.
Table 2 presents the results of XRD analyses which exhibit a wide range of mineralogical composition in O3w-S1l shale. Quartz and clay are the dominant minerals in the samples, and quartz content increases with a decrease of clay content. Quartz contents range from 28.9% to 69.1% with an average of 45.2%, whereas clay mineral contents average 35.0% with a range of 18.3%e61.1%. In addition, the content of carbonate minerals (calcite and dolomite) is between 0% and 16.7% with an average of 8.1%. The mixed-layer illite-smectite is the major mineral in clay minerals with its content of 9.83%~23.8%, followed by illite (2.75e34.2%) and chlorite (0.37e13.4%). Kaolinite and montmorillonite are not detected.
Total pore volume and total porosity obtained by helium porosimetry are given in Table 3. The value of total porosity varies from 4.72% to 7.08% with an average value of 5.78%. The total pore volume varies from 1.8 10 2 cm3/g to 2.9 10 2 cm3/g, with an average value of 2.3 10 2 cm3/g.

sections.heading: 5.2. Pore morphology from FE-SEM
sections.text:
FE-SEM analyses, which enable the observation of pore morphology, was performed on three samples from JY1 Well (JY101, JY1-04 and JY1-08) and one sample from JY11-4 Well (JY11-403) (Figs. 3e4). Overall, FE-SEM images show that pores in the samples are mainly within nm- and mm-size regimes. According to the descriptive classification scheme proposed by Loucks et al. (2012), matrix-related pores in shale can be classified as interP pore (pores between minerals particles and crystals), intraP pores (pore within particles) and OM pores. These pore types are all observed in this study. FE-SEM images of the organic-poor sample (JY1-01) from JY1Well are presented in Fig. 3aef, and show limited and isolated OM pores (Fig. 3aeb), intraP pores (Fig. 3c) and intercrystalline pores (Fig. 3d); these pores are observed within OM, quartz and pyrite framboids, respectively. OM pores in Sample JY1-01 are mainly irregular and elliptical with pore sizes from 5 nm to 400 nm. IntraP pores developed within quartz grains are often angular, linear or rounded in shape, with equivalent pore sizes varying from 50 nm to 180 nm (Fig. 3ced). A few nanometer-scale intercrystalline pores are observed within incompletely-filled pyrite framboids, but most of the intraP pores in pyrite framboids are filled with OM and/or clay minerals (Fig. 3d). Pyrite framboids in JY1-01 seem to be much less porous than other shale formations, such as Barnett shale (Loucks et al., 2012), Posidonia shale (Klaver et al., 2012) and Opalinus clay (Houben et al., 2014, 2013). In addition, a visible micro-fracture with 110 mm long and 100 nm width is also observed (Fig. 3eef), which may be caused by sample preparation or drying.
Compared with JY1-01, the number of pores in JY1-04 is larger and mainly dominated by OM pores with pore sizes from typically about 4 nme350 nm (Fig. 3gel). An overview of FE-SEM images for JY1-04 was taken at lower magnifications (Fig. 3g). Overall, pores in JY1-04 are irregular, bubble-like, elliptical and faveolate in shape, and commonly distributed independently within organic matter (Fig. 3iel). Other types of pores are rare in this sample even at higher magnifications. Areas between clay particles are often completely filled with OM, in which a large amount of pores developed (Fig. 3gei). According to the descriptive classification scheme (Loucks et al., 2012), pores developed in the OM-clay aggregates are also classified as OM pores (Fig. 3i). In a single OM particle, large volumes of OM pores appear to be heterogeneously distributed (Fig. 3jel).
Fig. 4 shows the FE-SEM images of organic-rich shales from JY108 (Fig. 4aef) and JY11-4-04 (Fig. 4gel). Similar to JY1-04, OM pores dominate the pore system in JY1-08, and these pores are heterogeneously distributed in organic matter with irregular and faveolate shapes (Fig. 4aed). Many pyrite framboids, which are completely filled with OM, are observed in JY1-08 on a micronscale. Also, organic matter, located within pyrite framboids, contains a significant numbers of nanometer-scale pores within OM

Even though OM pores are widely developed in JY1-08, there are still some organic grains exhibiting no or few nanoscale OM pores (Fig. 4eef), which is often thought to be associated with some differences of organic matter composition (Curtis et al., 2012). A similar phenomenon was observed for Woodford shale (Curtis et al., 2012). Almost all the observed pores are associated with OM, and other types of pores are not well developed. The OM pore morphologies encountered in discrete organic matter grains from JY11-4-03 are often bubble-like, elliptical, irregular, faveolated and elongate (Fig. 4hei, k-l). Intercrystalline areas within pyrite framboids are completely filled with organic matter; therefore these pores are not observed in JY11-4-03 (Fig. 4jek).

sections.heading: 5.3. Porosity from quantitative FE-SEM analysis
sections.text: Based on the visual inspections, a total of 89 high-resolution FESEM images from four samples were imported into the Image J software. In order to reduce the possible errors, the greyscale threshold values were assigned with the average threshold values, which enables a visual separation of pores from solid phases. sections.heading: 5.4.1. N2 adsorption/desorption curves
sections.text:
The N2 adsorption isotherms for all samples are given in Fig. 6. The reversed S-shaped N2 adsorption isotherms are type Ⅱ according to the Brunauer, Deming, Deming and Teller classification (Brunauer et al., 1940), indicating that samples are dominated by micropores and mesopores. A significant amount of adsorption at low relative pressure (<0.05), transiting from monomolecular to multi-molecular layer, is indicative of microporosity. Overall, samples from JY1 Well and JY11-4 Well exhibit similar isotherm shapes, and N2 adsorption volumes increase with TOC content. An exception is JY1-03 with a TOC content value of 1.70%, which is
slightly higher than JY1-01 (TOC ¼ 0.75%); both samples show a very similar adsorption volume. This suggests that the adsorption volume is controlled by factors other than TOC content, e.g. mineral composition. When the relative pressure is greater than 0.95, the adsorption volume increases rapidly and no adsorption saturation occurs, suggesting there may be some large pores or fractures in these shale samples.
Adsorption-desorption isotherms show clear hysteresis (Fig. 6). Different explanations have been proposed for hysteresis (Cohan, 1938; McGavack and Patrick, 1920; Sing, 1985), with the most likely explanation being capillary condensation in mesoporous structures (Sing, 1985). The shapes of hysteresis loops in S1l shales are similar to the H3 type according to IUPAC classification, suggesting the shape of the micropores in the sample are slit- or platelike (Sing, 1985). Compared with S1l shales, the shape of hysteresis loops in O1w shales can be classified as H2 type according to IUPAC classification, which is mainly associated with inkbottle pores and a small amount of cylindrical pores or parallel-plates (Sing, 1985). However, using the shape of hysteresis loop to explain the pore shape may be not accurate, because the actual pore shape may be a mix of different pores types which have also been observed from the FE-SEM images.

JY11-4-04 exhibits the highest BET surface area (27.06 m2/g), followed by JY1-08 (23.58 m2/g) and JY1-03 the least (12.17 m2/g), with the average of 19.49 m2/g. It is clear that the surface area increases with respect to TOC content, indicating that micropores are associated with organic matter. The volume of CO2 adsorption has a positive relationship with TOC contents (Fig. 8), suggesting that micropores are at least partly associated with organic matter. sections.heading: 5.5.2. Pore-size distribution, surface area and pore volume by CO2 adsorption
sections.text:
Plots of micropore volume and surface area versus pore width from CO2 adsorption are given in Fig. 9 and Table 5. It is observed that all samples have a multimodal distribution with the highest pore volume (1.74 10 2 cm3/g) at 0.48 nm from JY1-08. Fig. 9 shows that the micropore volume is mainly contributed by pores with a width less than 0.9 nm, and in this regime the increase rate
of surface area is much greater, which is also observed in Devonian and Mississippian New Albany shale (Mastalerz et al., 2013), and the Carboniferous Hurleg Formation in the eastern Qaidam Basin (Li et al., 2015). Four volumetric maxima are present at approximately 0.35, 0.48, 0.57 and 0.85 nm (Fig. 9aeb). The multimodal distribution of pores indicates the complex micropore structure in O3wS1l shale. The results also reveal that the variation in total micropore volume is relatively small (Table 5). JY11-4-04 has the highest micropore surface area of 17.4 m2/g, followed by JY1-06 (16.7m2/g), and JY1-03 the least (6.5 m2/g), with the average of 12.8 m2/g. The micropore volume of the samples varies between 2 10 3 cm3/g and 5 10 3 cm3/g, with an average of 3.6 10 3 cm3/g. When the pore width is greater than 0.9 nm, the value of micropore volume and surface area increase rate are very low and the distribution characteristic is similar among different samples. Micropore volumes are mainly contributed from the pores with a diameter less than 0.7 nm (Fig. 9). Macropore volume is obtained by subtracting the mesopore and mircopore volumes from the total pore volume (cm3/g) and the calculated results are also shown in Table 5. Macropore volumes in shale samples range from 2 10 3 to 8 10 3 cm3/g, and almost all values are much smaller than mesopore volumes, suggesting that the total pore volumes are mainly contributed by mesopores.

sections.heading: 5.6. Fractal dimensions from N2 adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
According to the FHH model, the plots of lnV versus ln(ln(P/Po)) and calculated fractal dimension results are shown in Fig. 10 and Table 6. Diagrams show that the separation into two ranges can allow us to separate two quite different gradients, which represent two significant phases of N2 adsorption process, i.e. monolayermultilayer adsorption and pore infilling. Both segments have a good linear relation and all the correlation coefficients are greater than 0.96, suggesting O3w-S1l shales are fractal (Jaroniec,1995). It is also observed that, with the decrease of relative pressure in the 2nd segment, a few data begin to deviate the fitted straight linewhich is mainly related with the increasing van der Waals force in the micropores. These data also reflect the occurence of monolayer adsorption process which provides the theoretical basis to calculate surface area in porous shale (Gregg and Sing, 1982).
The fractal dimension in the 1st segment (D1) varies between 2.737 and 2.823; while the fractal dimension in the 2nd segment (D2) changes from 1.692 to 1.845. The values of D2 are smaller than 2, which deviate from the definition of fractal dimension, are considered to be invalid and meaningless (Pfeifer and Avnir, 1983). sections.heading: 6.1. Comparison of porosities obtained from different methods
sections.text:
The accuratemeasurement of porosity in heterogeneous shale is a challenge because of the presence of nm-scale pores and reactive clay minerals (Klaver et al., 2015; Zargari et al., 2014). Conventional methods for porosity measurement, which are commonly used in sandstone or carbonate rocks, are often not applicable. In this study, three methods, including helium porosimetry, gas adsorption (CO2 and N2 adsorption) and quantitative FE-SEM analyses, were conducted to compare porosity or pore volume (Table 3). Both gas adsorption (CO2 and N2 adsorption) and helium porosimetry are widely accepted to effectively measure the pore volume in shale
samples (Mastalerz et al., 2013), and SEM images analyses have also been used to quantify porosity (Houben et al., 2014; Jiao et al., 2014; Shi et al., 2015); however, few researchers have compared these methods.
From Table 3, we can see that pore volumes determined from gas adsorption (CO2 and N2 adsorption) are equal to, or smaller than, those obtained by helium porosimetry. The largest difference between gas (CO2 and N2) adsorption and helium porosimetry is noted for JY11-4-04 with a difference of 9 10 2 cm3/g. However, some pore volumes obtained by helium porosimetry is larger, which is also observed in previous studies (Chalmers et al., 2012 a; Mastalerz et al., 2013; Rexer et al., 2014; Ross and Bustin, 2009). The reasons for this phenomenon are not certain, but are generally thought to be related to the specific pore size range that different probe gas (CO2, N2 and helium) measures. Low pressure gas N2 adsorption is applicable for pore diameters between 2 nm and 300 nm, whereas CO2 was usually used to characterize micropores (<2 nm in diameter) that are more accessible for CO2 than for N2, and helium pycnometry can covers all accessible pore size (Chalmers et al., 2012 a; Mastalerz et al., 2013; Ross and Bustin, 2009). Rexer et al. (2014) reported that some overlap exists between N2 and CO2 adsorption, and CO2 sorption pore volume accounts for pores up to approximately 5.6 nm in Posidonia shales. In addition, helium pycnometry was carried out on a cylinder (2.5 cm high with diameter of 2.5 cm in this study) while low pressure gas adsorptions were carried out on crushed samples (60e80 mesh), thus, the accessible pore volume may differ between these techniques with different sample sizes. Similar specific pore size range has also been observed in MIP with pore size down to 3 nm in diameter (Mastalerz et al., 2013; Ross and Bustin, 2009). The above factors could result in differences between helium porosimetry and gas (CO2 and N2) adsorption; however, our results show that the pore volumes measured by helium porosimetry and gas (CO2 and N2) adsorption are comparable (Table 3), which may reflect that macropores with pore size larger than 300 nm are limited in O3wS1l shale.
On the contrary, the averaged OM porosity, the ratio of OM pore volume to the shale bulk volume, determined by FE-SEM images using Image J software on four samples shows a wide range from 0.29% to 2.53%. It is noted that FE-SEM image OM porosities are much lower than those obtained by helium pycnometry and the porosity difference between them is around 4%, which is mainly related to the limited resolution of FE-SEM images. As for the FESEM images, only the pores above the practical pore resolution can be identified and segmented, whereas the pores smaller in area than the practical pore resolution cannot be accurately imaged, segmented and counted (Houben et al., 2014, 2013; Klaver et al., 2015). However, according to gas adsorption results, micropore and mesopore volume are mainly contributed by pores with a width less than 0.9 nm and pores from 2 nm to about 30 nm.
Furthermore, the shale is often heterogeneous and complex, and the FE-SEM images only provide insights in the limited areas, which may not be representative of larger sized samples used in helium porosity and low-pressure gas adsorption.

sections.heading: 6.2. Pore genesis and development: evidence from pore morphology and distribution
sections.text:
The development of porosity in mudstone is a complicated process which is often associated with compaction (including both chemical and mechanical compaction), carbonate precipitation, hydrocarbon generation, asphaltene filling, dissolution, and other factors (Aplin and Macquaker, 2011; Aplin et al., 2006; Jiao et al., 2014; Mastalerz et al., 2013). Among them, mechanical compaction may be the most significant process in mud diagenesis (Loucks et al., 2012). Because of compaction process, a large amount of interP and intraP pores were lost during the burial stage. Previous studies also revealed that pores in source rock have a strong relationship with the hydrocarbon generation and large OM pores are produced during the process of maturation (Chalmers and Bustin, 2008; Curtis et al., 2012; Jarvie et al., 2007; Milliken et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2013). Porosity variation in the shale with respect to thermal maturity reveals the variation of OM porosity to some extent (Valenza et al., 2013). The cross-sections of pores caused by hydrocarbon generation are usually circular and elliptical (Loucks et al., 2009). However, the type and shape of pores can be influenced and transformed by the combination of multiple diagenetic processes. For example, asphaltene filling and carbonate precipitation can hinder pore development to result in smaller porosity (Rexer et al., 2014).
The high-resolution FE-SEM images make it possible to investigate pore genesis and development in shales. FE-SEM images show that OM pores are the dominant ones in organic-rich shale samples and these OM pores are often irregular, bubble-like, elliptical and faveolate in shape (Figs. 3e4). The values of thermal maturity, converted from the bitumen reflectance, of all samples are above 2.0%, indicating the over-mature nature of O3w-S1l shale samples. Thus these OM pores are most likely caused by hydrocarbon generation and expulsion (Chalmers and Bustin, 2008; Curtis et al., 2012; Jarvie et al., 2007; Milliken et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2013). Due to the small size and great frictional forces on the bubble walls, most OM pores maintained their original size and shape during the deep-burial process, while some macropores may be deformed by strong compaction or asphaltene filling.
There are also other pore types in the SEM images shown in Fig. 3, which may form by different mechanisms or processes. Images from JY1-01 shows limited intraP pores and intercrystalline pores (Fig. 3aed), which are observed within quartz and pyrite framboids, respectively. IntraP pores shown in Fig. 3ced are likely formed by partial dissolution of carbonate and/or feldspar grains. Even though, carbonate and feldspar grains are rigid grains and resistant to compaction, they are also chemically unstable and may undergo dissolution, forming intraP pores (Aplin and Macquaker, 2011; Aplin et al., 2006; Loucks et al., 2012). It is reported that some of the intercrystalline pores within pyrite framboids are primary in origin; however most of these pores are probably diagenetic (Jiao et al., 2014; Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Milliken et al., 2013). When the kerogen is mature, most OM was filled in the interP pores between pyrite particles and intraP pores in framboids. Because the OM is much softer than the mineral matrix, the filled
OM can act as a favorable path for hydrocarbon migration, during which, some heavy ends (such as asphaltene) can remain in these pores and result in the decrease of porosity (Jiao et al., 2014; Milliken et al., 2013). Some of the residual materials from the hydrocarbon migration can generate further micropores, which is supported by the observation of pores in organic matter infilling pyrite framboids (Fig. 4c).

sections.heading: 6.3. Relationships between pore structure parameters and TOC content
sections.text:
To investigate the relationship of TOC content and the pore structure parameters in O3w-S1l shale, related plots are given in Figs. 11e12. TOC values of eight shale samples suggest a positive correlation (correlation coefficient of 0.80) with the quartz content (Fig. 11a), which is also observed in Devonian Horn River shale, Canada (Dong et al., 2015). The positive relationship also suggests
that the quartz is partially biogenic in origin, and this was confirmed by the enrichment of graptolite and radiolarian (Guo, 2013), and several lines of evidence by Wang et al. (2014). A positive relationship occurs between TOC content and porosity from helium pycnometry and OM porosity from FE-SEM images (Fig. 11b), which is consistent with the variation tendency in Marcellus formation when the TOC content is below 5.6 wt.% (Milliken et al., 2013). The positive relationship between TOC content and porosity can also be observed in FE-SEM images (Figs. 3e4). The TOC contents in JY1-01, JY1-04, JY1-08 and JY11-4-04 are 0.75, 2.05, 4.03 and 3.35 wt.%, respectively. It can be observed that the visible pore area (the sum of all pores) increases significantly with respect to TOC content (Figs. 3e4).
In addition, a positive relationship also obviously exists between TOC content and micropore surface area with a correlation coefficient of 0.86 (Fig. 12a). Similar correlations occur between TOC content and micropore volume (Fig. 12b) and BET surface area
(Fig. 12c), with correlation coefficients of 0.92 and 0.86, respectively. These good relationships indicate that OM can be used as a parameter to describe the micropores in O3w-S1l shale, and shale samples with a higher TOC content tend to have more micropores, larger surface areas and micropore volumes, which are consistent with previous studies (Liu et al., 2015; Xiong et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2014).
However, the relationship between the average pore size and TOC content is not apparent with a correlation coefficient of 0.6 (Fig. 12d). The moderate relationship also suggests samples with a higher TOC content often contain more small pores, resulting in the overall decrease of average pore size in O3w-S1l shale. The decreasing average pore size and increasing micropore surface area may directly contribute to the positive relationship between fractal dimension and TOC content (Fig. 12e), which is also observed in the Lower Cambrian Niutitang formation in the Sichuan Basin (Yang
et al., 2014) and in Chang-7 shale from the Upper Triassic Yanchang formation in Ordos Basin (Liu et al., 2015).
We report that O3w-S1l shale is fractal with a fractal dimension varying from 2.737 to 2.823. Shale samples with a higher TOC content tend to contain more heterogeneous micropores, resulting in higher fractal dimensions andmore complicated pore structures. The shale samples with a higher fractal dimension also tend to be able to inhibit gas desorption and flow (Yang et al., 2014). No apprent relationships exist between mesopore volume and TOC content (Fig. 12f), which further illustrates that OM has a greater contribution to micropores rather than mesopores.

sections.heading: 6.4. Relationships between mineral composition and pore structure parameters
sections.text:
To investigate the relationships between main minerals and
pore structure parameters in O3w-S1l shale, the related plots are given in Fig. 13. XRD results show that quartz and clay are the dominant minerals (Table 2). Almost all of the relationships between quartz and pore structure parameters are positive, with the correlation coefficients between quartz andmicropore surface area, micropore volume, BET surface and total pore volume are 0.77, 0.82, 0.76 and 0.71, respectively (Fig. 13aed). The positive relationships between quartz content and surface and total volume are similar to previous work on Devonian gas shales (Chalmers et al., 2012b), but opposite to a study of Chang-7 shale from the Upper Triassic Yanchang formation in Ordos Basin (Xiong et al., 2015). Distinct relationships in different areas may relate to the origin of quartz, sedimentary environment or diagenetic maturity. Chang-7 shales in the Yanchang formation were deposited in fluvial and lacustrine environments and the origin of quartz is mainly terrigenous (Zeng et al., 2014), while the O3w-S1l shale was deposited in a deep-water shelf sedimentary environment where the quartz is mainly of biogenic origin (Wang et al., 2014).
In addition, the values of vitrinite reflectance in Chang-7 shale vary from 1.2% to 1.42% (Zeng et al., 2014), suggesting a middle-tohigh maturity and in the middle diagenesis stage, while O3w-S1l shale is over-mature with a vitrinite reflectance greater than 2.0% and in the late diagenetic stage. The above difference may account for the different relationships between quartz, surface area and total pore volume. Even though the relationship between quartz and fractal dimension is not obvious, with a correlation coefficient of only 0.42 (Fig. 13e), there is still an increasing trend in fractal dimension values with increasing quartz contents. This increasing trend, which is different to previous studies on Chang-7 shale and Wufeng shale (Liang et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2015), may relate to microfractures, which would complicate the relationship. Besides, the relationship between quartz and average pore size is also complicated (Fig. 13f), which may be related to the development of intraparticle dissolution micropores in quartz grain (Fig. 3ced).
In contrast, the relationships between clay minerals and pore structures parameters (micropore surface area and volume, BET
structure parameter in O3w ~ S1l shale. (a) Pore surface area; (b) Micropore volume; (c) k circles represent the content of clay minerals and the solid boxes represent the quartz
surface area, total pore volume, fractal dimension and average pore size) show quite different trends (Fig. 13), suggesting that quartz and clayminerals have different impacts on pore structures of O3wS1l shale. This conclusion is different from a previous study of Chang-7 shale from the Upper Triassic Yanchang formation, Ordos Basin (Liu et al., 2015), Fort Simpson shales from northern British Columbia, western Canada (Ross and Bustin, 2009) and Wufeng shale in the southwest region of the Sichuan Basin (Xiong et al., 2015). Negative relationships, shown in Fig. 13aed, indicate that the micropore surface area and total pore decrease with increasing clay minerals contents in O3w-S1l shale. Even though, clay-rich O3w-S1l shales, which have the comparable TOC content and maturity, still make a contribution of clayminerals to themicropore structure, which is consistent with previous studies (Rexer et al., 2014; Ross and Bustin, 2009). Higher clay contents may allow the collapse of OM pores if there are insufficient rigid grains, such as quartz, feldspars, pyrite, calcite and skeletal materials, to preserve these pores (Fishman et al., 2012; Milliken et al., 2013). This decreasing trend is also consistent with observations in FE-SEM images in this study. JY1-04 is rich in clay minerals with a content of 39.3%, while the value of clay minerals in JY11-4-03 is only 27.1%. Pores are rounder in JY11-4-03 compared to JY1-04. Different TOC content in these two samples may also have some effect on pore shape, which was also observed in a recent study of Klaver et al. (2015).

sections.heading: 6.5. Relationships between fractal dimension and pore structure parameters
sections.text:
Fig. 14 shows the relationships between fractal dimension and pore structure parameters in O3w-S1l shale. Positive relationships obviously exist between the fractal dimension and micropore volume, micropore surface area and BET surface area (Fig. 14aec), with
a correlation coefficient of 0.70, 0.66 and 0.64, respectively. These positive relationships are consistent with previous studies (Liang et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2014) and suggest shale samples with higher fractal dimension values tend to have a greater surface area and larger micropore volume. However, the relationship between fractal dimension and average pore size is negative, indicating that fractal dimension increases rapidly with the decrease of pore size (Fig. 14d). This finding was also observed in the pore structure study for other shales (Liu et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2014), and for coal (Yao et al., 2008). When the average pore sizes are smaller than 5 nm, the fractal dimension is greater than 2.82, suggesting a very irregular and complex pore structure in O3w-S1l shale samples. When the sizes are larger than 5 nm, the values of fractal dimension decrease significantly, indicating a more regular pore structure (Fig. 14d). Therefore, fractal dimension can be used as an effective parameter to reflect the complexity of pore structure and the degree of micropore development in O3w-S1l shale. It is also noted that the relationships between fractal dimension and total pore volume and mesopore volume are weak (Fig. 14eef), which is not consistent with the work of Liu et al. (2015). It is suggested that some other factors, such as the development of microfractures, may also influence and result in the weak relationships. Generally, total pore volume can increase with the development of macropores or microfractures; nevertheless, fractal dimension is mainly associated with the complexity of micropores in the shale. According to the shape of hysteresis loop of N2 adsorption, micropores in shale samples are mainly slit- or platelike with a mix of different other pore shapes. SEM images also show that there are four types of pore with diameters from nanometers to micrometers. sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
Based on our results, the following conclusions can be reached from O3w-S1l shale:
(1) Pore morphology is quite different between organic-rich and organic-poor shale samples, which reflects different pore genesis and development process. In the organic-rich samples, OM pores are dominant and are mainly associated with hydrocarbon generation. While in organic-poor samples, both isolated interP pores, intraP pores and OM pores are observed and the former two pores are likely formed by partial dissolution of carbonate and/or feldspar grains. Intercrystalline pores within pyrite framboids are primary in origin; however most of these pores are probably diagenetic. (2) Pore volumes or porosities obtained from helium porosimetry are comparable with those determined by gas adsorption (CO2 and N2 adsorption), reflecting limited macropores with pore size larger than 300 nm in O3w-S1l shale. However, OM porosity determined by quantitative FE-SEM analyses is much smaller, which is mainly related to limited resolution and the smaller observation areas. (3) Shale samples with higher TOC contents have more micropores, which results in a more complex pore structure. Micropore surface area and total pore volume decrease with increasing clay minerals contents; however, clay-rich O3wS1l shales still make certain contribution to the micropore structure. (4) O3w-S1l shales are fractal and the fractal dimensions of pores are mainly associated with micropores. Shale samples with higher fractal dimension values tend to have a greater surface area and larger micropore volume. Therefore, fractal dimension is an effective parameter to reflect the complexity of pore structure and the degree of micropore development in O3w-S1l shale.

Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), low pressure gas (N2 and CO2) adsorption, helium pycnometry, X-ray diffraction and geochemical analyses were performed to investigate the pore structure and fractal dimension of the pores in O3w-S1l shale formation in the Jiaoshiba area. Reversed S-shaped isotherms obtained from nitrogen adsorption are type II, and hysteresis loops indicate that the shape of micropore in the samples is slit-or plate-like.
